text: Which gland is primarily responsible for the aqueous component of the tear film?
rationale: The lacrimal gland produces the main aqueous layer; Meibomian glands secrete lipids.

text: A 4-year-old presents with chronic tearing and crusting at the inner canthus. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
rationale: Persistent epiphora and discharge in infancy indicate incomplete nasolacrimal duct canalization.

text: Which corneal layer serves as the main barrier to fluid influx from the anterior chamber?
rationale: The corneal endothelium maintains deturgescence via its Na+/K+ ATPase pump system.

text: A contact lens wearer develops an oval peripheral stromal infiltrate with intact epithelium after sleeping in lenses. What is the most likely cause?
rationale: Overnight lens wear may trigger a sterile peripheral infiltrate from localized immune response to bacterial antigens.

text: Which type of cataract is most commonly associated with prolonged corticosteroid use?
condition: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre- & Post-Operative Care
rationale: Steroid exposure leads to posterior subcapsular lens opacification near the visual axis.

text: Accommodation results primarily from contraction of which muscle?
condition: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre- & Post-Operative Care
rationale: Ciliary muscle contraction relaxes zonules, allowing the lens to become more convex for near focus.

text: Which structure forms the blood–aqueous barrier in the eye?
choices: Non-pigmented ciliary epithelium and iris capillary endothelium
rationale: Tight junctions of non-pigmented ciliary epithelium and iris vessels regulate entry of plasma components.

text: A patient with photophobia, circumlimbal flush, and small pupil most likely has inflammation of which structure?
rationale: These signs indicate anterior uveitis affecting iris and ciliary body tissues.

text: Which retinal layer contains the photoreceptor outer segments?
choices: Outer segment layer (external to external limiting membrane)
rationale: Outer segments contain discs with photopigments essential for phototransduction.

text: A 30-year-old presents with punched-out chorioretinal scars and peripapillary atrophy. Which diagnosis best fits?
rationale: Triad of peripapillary atrophy, punched-out scars, and absence of vitritis characterizes Presumed Ocular Histoplasmosis Syndrome.

text: Which visual field defect is most typical of early glaucomatous damage?
rationale: Localized arcuate and nasal step defects occur first due to selective ganglion cell loss at the lamina.

text: A 70-year-old with sudden, painless unilateral vision loss and chalky white optic disc swelling likely has:
choices: Arteritic Anterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (Giant Cell Arteritis)
rationale: Arteritic AION presents with pallid swelling and profound vision loss; ESR/CRP should be checked immediately.

text: A painless, firm nodule within the tarsal plate that has persisted for several weeks is most consistent with:
rationale: Chalazion is a sterile lipogranulomatous inflammation of a Meibomian gland.

text: Chronic anterior blepharitis is most often associated with overgrowth of which organism?
rationale: Staphylococcal toxins chronically inflame the eyelid margin causing collarettes.

text: The most common malignant eyelid tumor is:
rationale: Basal cell carcinoma accounts for ~90% of eyelid malignancies, typically on the lower lid.

text: Recurrent erosions and map-dot-fingerprint patterns describe:
rationale: EBMD affects the basal epithelial layer causing poor adhesion and irregular basement membrane.

text: Guttata and stromal edema on slit-lamp indicate endothelial pump failure typical of:
rationale: Fuchs causes Descemet thickening and endothelial loss, producing morning blur and glare.

text: Dendritic epithelial ulcers stain with fluorescein and rose bengal. The likely cause is:
rationale: HSV keratitis produces branching ulcers with terminal bulbs.

text: A patient with a contact-lens–related corneal ulcer and hypopyon most likely has infection by:
rationale: Pseudomonas is the most common cause of severe bacterial keratitis in lens wearers.

text: Which systemic disease classically causes “snowflake” cataracts?
condition: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre- & Post-Operative Care
rationale: Chronic hyperglycemia leads to sorbitol accumulation and subcapsular opacities.

text: A congenital cataract in an infant with cardiac defects and deafness suggests:
condition: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre- & Post-Operative Care
rationale: Rubella during first trimester interferes with lens fiber development.

text: Brunescent discoloration and increased myopia with age indicate:
condition: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre- & Post-Operative Care
rationale: Nuclear sclerosis increases refractive index, causing a myopic shift (“second sight”).

text: Bilateral granulomatous uveitis with mutton-fat keratic precipitates is typical of:
rationale: Sarcoidosis causes granulomatous anterior uveitis with large greasy precipitates.

text: Recurrent acute anterior uveitis in a young male with back pain most likely indicates:
rationale: Ankylosing spondylitis and reactive arthritis produce HLA-B27–positive acute uveitis.

text: A “snowbank” of exudate over the pars plana is characteristic of:
rationale: Inflammation localized to the vitreous base produces white exudates along the ora serrata.

text: Posterior uveitis with placoid chorioretinitis and positive VDRL suggests:
rationale: Treponemal infection can cause multifocal chorioretinitis and vasculitis.

text: Sudden, painless monocular vision loss with a cherry-red spot on macula indicates:
rationale: Central retinal artery occlusion causes inner retinal ischemia leaving foveal choroidal flush.

text: A patient presents with diffuse retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, and macular edema described as a “blood and thunder” fundus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
rationale: CRVO shows venous dilation and widespread intraretinal hemorrhages due to thrombotic occlusion.

text: Sectoral hemorrhages confined to one quadrant of the retina are characteristic of:
rationale: BRVO results from venous compression at arteriovenous crossings, often superotemporal.

text: Which systemic disease is most strongly associated with retinal microaneurysms, dot-blot hemorrhages, and hard exudates?
rationale: Capillary basement-membrane thickening and pericyte loss produce classic non-proliferative diabetic changes.

text: Cotton-wool spots, arteriovenous nicking, and flame hemorrhages on fundus exam are most typical of:
rationale: Chronic hypertension causes arteriolar narrowing, exudation, and superficial nerve-fiber hemorrhages.

text: Sea-fan neovascularization with peripheral “salmon-patch” hemorrhages occurs in:
rationale: Retinal ischemia from sickled erythrocytes leads to neovascular fronds resembling sea fans.

text: The hallmark of exudative (wet) age-related macular degeneration is:
rationale: Choroidal neovascular membrane formation under the RPE causes hemorrhage and exudation leading to rapid vision loss.

text: Drusen located between the RPE and Bruch’s membrane are characteristic of:
rationale: Hard and soft drusen mark dry AMD, the non-neovascular precursor stage.

text: Which inherited macular dystrophy presents with an “egg-yolk” lesion in the fovea during childhood?
rationale: Best disease (VMD2 gene) causes lipofuscin accumulation forming the vitelliform lesion.

text: A young adult male with metamorphopsia and a serous detachment of the neurosensory retina most likely has:
rationale: CSC occurs from choroidal hyperpermeability and RPE leakage, common in stressed males.

text: The main site of resistance to aqueous outflow in primary open-angle glaucoma is the:
rationale: The juxtacanalicular portion of the trabecular meshwork offers the greatest outflow resistance.

text: Secondary open-angle glaucoma due to red blood cells in the anterior chamber is termed:
rationale: Degenerated erythrocytes obstruct the trabecular meshwork after vitreous hemorrhage.

text: Which finding is most suggestive of normal-tension glaucoma?
choices: Disc hemorrhage and focal notching with IOP < 21 mm Hg
Diffuse cupping with IOP > 35 mm Hg
Shallow anterior chamber and angle closure
rationale: Normal-tension glaucoma shows glaucomatous optic nerve damage despite statistically normal intraocular pressure.

text: Krukenberg spindle, iris transillumination defects, and dense trabecular pigment characterize:
rationale: Reverse pupillary block causes posterior iris bowing and pigment release.

text: Pseudoexfoliative glaucoma is caused by deposition of abnormal fibrillar material primarily on the:
choices: Lens capsule and anterior segment structures
rationale: Pseudoexfoliative material accumulates on the anterior lens surface and iris, clogging outflow pathways.

text: Pallor of the temporal optic disc with central scotoma is most consistent with:
rationale: Demyelinating optic neuritis typically causes central visual loss and temporal pallor on recovery.

text: Bilateral disc swelling with preserved visual acuity is most often due to:
rationale: Papilledema reflects elevated intracranial pressure transmitted via the optic nerve sheath.

text: A central or cecocentral scotoma is typically seen in:
rationale: Mitochondrial or nutritional damage to papillomacular bundle fibers produces central defects.

text: Optic nerve head drusen can mimic papilledema but are differentiated by:
choices: Autofluorescence or B-scan showing calcified bodies
Enlarged blind spot with normal imaging
rationale: Drusen are calcified deposits causing pseudopapilledema without true swelling; autofluorescence or B-scan reveals the calcified bodies.

text: The most common cause of flashes and floaters in middle age is:
rationale: Vitreous liquefaction leads to posterior vitreous detachment, causing traction on the retina and symptoms of photopsia and floaters.

text: A Weiss ring indicates detachment of the vitreous from:
rationale: A circular opacity (Weiss ring) represents the glial tissue at the optic nerve head that separates from the disc during posterior vitreous detachment.

text: Calcified spherical opacities suspended in the vitreous describe:
rationale: Asteroid bodies are calcium–lipid complexes that float within the vitreous gel, seen as multiple small white spheres.

text: Horseshoe-shaped retinal tears occur most often from:
choices: Vitreoretinal traction during posterior vitreous detachment
rationale: Acute traction during posterior vitreous detachment can avulse a flap of retina, creating a horseshoe tear that predisposes to rhegmatogenous detachment.

text: Which is the most common type of retinal detachment?
rationale: Rhegmatogenous detachments account for the majority of cases; they result from full-thickness retinal breaks allowing liquefied vitreous into the subretinal space.

text: Subretinal fluid without retinal breaks suggests:
choices: Exudative (detachment from choroidal inflammation or tumor)
rationale: Exudative (serous) detachments occur when inflammatory, vascular or neoplastic processes leak fluid under the retina without a break.

text: Retinoschisis differs from detachment because:
choices: It splits retinal layers and is non‑mobile
rationale: True retinoschisis is an intraretinal splitting—often at the outer plexiform layer—producing a smooth, immobile elevation rather than free‑floating neurosensory retina.

text: “Berlin edema” describes:
rationale: Commotio retinae from blunt trauma causes transient photoreceptor disruption, producing a gray‑white, milky appearance sometimes called Berlin edema.

text: A teardrop‑shaped pupil directed inferonasally suggests:
rationale: When the globe ruptures, the iris may prolapse toward the wound, creating a peaked or teardrop pupil directed toward the rupture site.

text: Intraocular foreign bodies of metallic origin can cause:
rationale: Iron particles left in the eye undergo oxidative reactions that deposit hemosiderin, leading to siderosis with retinal and lens degeneration.

text: “Vossius ring” on the anterior lens capsule results from:
choices: Pigment imprint of the pupil margin after blunt trauma
rationale: A circular pigment ring on the lens capsule (Vossius ring) forms when blunt trauma presses the iris margin against the lens, leaving a deposit of pigment.

text: The most vision‑threatening complication of an open‑globe injury is:
rationale: Microbial contamination of an open globe can lead to fulminant endophthalmitis and loss of the eye if not promptly treated.

text: Proptosis with lid retraction and diplopia in a hyperthyroid patient indicates:
rationale: Autoimmune orbital inflammation (Graves orbitopathy) causes extraocular muscle enlargement and fibrosis, leading to proptosis, eyelid retraction and diplopia in hyperthyroid patients.

text: Painful ophthalmoplegia with normal thyroid tests suggests:
rationale: Tolosa–Hunt syndrome is an idiopathic granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus causing recurrent painful ophthalmoplegia without thyroid dysfunction.

text: Which systemic autoimmune disease most commonly causes scleritis?
rationale: Scleritis is often associated with systemic autoimmune disease; rheumatoid arthritis is the most frequent culprit in necrotizing and diffuse forms.

text: Episcleritis is distinguished from scleritis by:
choices: Bright‑red, mobile vessels that blanch with phenylephrine
Deep violaceous hue and severe pain
rationale: Superficial episcleral vessels move over the sclera and constrict with topical phenylephrine, whereas scleritis presents with deeper, purple vessels and significant pain.

text: Bilateral lacrimal gland enlargement and dry eye symptoms are seen in:
rationale: Non‑caseating granulomas of sarcoidosis commonly infiltrate the lacrimal glands, leading to enlargement and keratoconjunctivitis sicca.

text: Which cranial nerve controls the superior oblique muscle?
rationale: The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) innervates the superior oblique, which intorts, depresses, and abducts the eye when adducted.

text: A patient with a “down and out” eye and ptosis likely has a lesion of:
rationale: Oculomotor nerve palsy paralyzes most extraocular muscles and the levator palpebrae, resulting in ptosis and a ‘down‑and‑out’ eye due to unopposed actions of CN IV and CN VI.

text: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is caused by a lesion in the:
rationale: The medial longitudinal fasciculus links the abducens and oculomotor nuclei; damage prevents adduction of the ipsilateral eye and causes nystagmus of the abducting eye.

text: Anisocoria greater in dark with ptosis and anhidrosis indicates:
rationale: Horner syndrome results from loss of sympathetic innervation; miosis is more pronounced in dim light, often accompanied by ptosis and ipsilateral anhidrosis.

text: A lesion of the optic chiasm typically produces:
rationale: Crossing nasal fibers are interrupted at the optic chiasm, leading to loss of temporal visual fields in both eyes—bitemporal hemianopia.

text: A right occipital lobe lesion causes:
rationale: The occipital cortex processes contralateral visual fields; a right occipital lesion leads to left homonymous hemianopia.

text: Macular sparing with homonymous hemianopia is due to:
choices: Dual blood supply from posterior and middle cerebral arteries
rationale: Because the macular cortex receives collateral supply from both posterior and middle cerebral arteries, some central vision is preserved despite occipital lesions.

text: Salt‑and‑pepper retinopathy is classically associated with:
rationale: Congenital rubella infection disrupts retinal pigment epithelium, producing diffuse mottling—a salt‑and‑pepper fundus.

text: Cotton‑ball exudates near the optic disc in an immunocompromised patient suggest:
rationale: Cytomegalovirus causes necrotizing retinitis in AIDS patients, producing fluffy white exudates (‘cotton balls’) near the optic nerve and arcades.

text: “Headlight in the fog” appearance describes:
rationale: Toxoplasmosis retinochoroiditis causes a bright, necrotic lesion with intense vitritis, giving the impression of a headlight shining through fog.

text: Subretinal “tunnel” lesions in infants born prematurely with oxygen therapy indicate:
rationale: Excess oxygen suppresses retinal vascular growth; subsequent hypoxia triggers neovascularization and fibrovascular proliferation characteristic of retinopathy of prematurity.

text: The primary pathology in keratoconus occurs within the:
choices: Stromal collagen lamellae and Bowman’s layer
rationale: Keratoconus involves stromal thinning and breaks in Bowman’s layer, leading to progressive conical deformation of the cornea.

text: Vogt’s striae are:
choices: Vertical stress lines in posterior stroma of keratoconus
rationale: Fine vertical lines in the posterior stroma and Descemet’s membrane (Vogt’s striae) appear in advanced keratoconus and disappear with gentle pressure.

text: Band keratopathy represents deposition of:
rationale: Chronic ocular inflammation or systemic hypercalcemia can cause calcium salt deposition in Bowman’s layer and superficial stroma, creating a horizontal band opacity.

text: Fleischer ring in keratoconus is caused by:
rationale: A brownish ring (Fleischer ring) around the base of the cone is due to hemosiderin (iron) deposition in the basal epithelial cells of keratoconic corneas.

text: The most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults is:
rationale: Choroidal melanoma arises from uveal melanocytes and is the leading primary intraocular malignancy in adults.

text: Leukocoria in a child is most commonly due to:
rationale: Retinoblastoma often presents as leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) in children and is a life‑threatening malignant retinal tumor.

text: “Flexner–Wintersteiner rosettes” are pathognomonic for:
rationale: Histologic examination of retinoblastoma shows Flexner–Wintersteiner rosettes—arrangements of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen—indicating photoreceptor differentiation.

text: Pinguecula differs from pterygium because it:
rationale: Pinguecula is a benign elastotic degeneration confined to the bulbar conjunctiva and does not grow over the cornea like a pterygium.

text: A wing‑shaped fibrovascular growth onto the cornea is a:
rationale: Chronic UV exposure induces pterygium formation— a triangular fibrovascular growth crossing the limbus, often with an iron (Stocker) line at its head.

text: Giant papillary conjunctivitis is commonly associated with:
rationale: Chronic mechanical irritation from contact lenses or sutures causes large, cobblestone‑like papillae on the tarsal conjunctiva—giant papillary conjunctivitis.

text: A corneal ulcer with feathery borders and satellite infiltrates is most likely caused by:
rationale: Filamentous fungi such as Fusarium/Aspergillus produce branching feathery margins and satellite lesions.

text: A ring-shaped stromal infiltrate with severe pain out of proportion to findings suggests:
rationale: Acanthamoeba infection often follows tap-water lens cleaning and causes a ring infiltrate and significant pain.

text: The dendritic ulcer of HSV keratitis stains with:
choices: Fluorescein and rose bengal at the edges
rationale: Active viral epithelium takes fluorescein centrally and rose bengal along infected borders.

text: The most common indication for penetrating keratoplasty in the U.S. is:
rationale: Keratoconus accounts for the majority of full-thickness grafts in younger patients.

text: A Khoda ring (white circular infiltrate at the graft margin) indicates:
rationale: A white ring of inflammatory cells at the host–graft junction is a classic sign of endothelial rejection.

text: A slow-growing, pearly ulcerated lesion on the lower lid is most consistent with:
rationale: Basal cell carcinoma is the most common eyelid malignancy, typically on the lower lid and medial canthus.

text: The most lethal primary eyelid tumor is:
rationale: Sebaceous carcinoma often arises from meibomian glands and metastasizes early.

text: The Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase maintains:
choices: Low intracellular Na⁺ and high K⁺
rationale: The pump actively transports 3 Na⁺ out and 2 K⁺ in, preserving resting potential.

text: Resting membrane potential primarily depends on permeability to:
rationale: Potassium conductance dominates via leak channels, setting the resting potential.

text: Depolarization occurs when:
rationale: Rapid Na⁺ entry drives the upstroke of the action potential.

text: Repolarization of a neuron is due to:
choices: Efflux of K⁺ through voltage-gated channels
rationale: Opening of K⁺ channels allows efflux and restores the negative potential.

text: Myelin increases conduction velocity by:
choices: Saltatory conduction between nodes of Ranvier
rationale: Myelin insulates the axon; impulses jump from node to node, speeding conduction.

text: The main excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS is:
rationale: Glutamate activates NMDA and AMPA receptors to excite neurons.

text: The chief inhibitory transmitter in the brain is:
rationale: GABA opens Cl⁻ channels, causing hyperpolarization and inhibition.

text: Calcium influx at the nerve terminal triggers:
rationale: Ca²⁺ binds synaptotagmin and initiates exocytosis of synaptic vesicles.

text: The refractory period occurs because:
rationale: Inactivation gates of Na⁺ channels prevent re-excitation until channels reset.

text: Rod photoreceptors hyperpolarize in response to:
rationale: Light converts 11-cis to all-trans retinal; cGMP falls, closing Na⁺ channels and hyperpolarizing the cell.

text: The dark current in photoreceptors results from:
rationale: In darkness, cGMP keeps Na⁺ channels open, producing a depolarized ‘dark current’.

text: Cone cells differ from rods by:
rationale: Cones mediate photopic color vision and adapt quickly compared to rods.

text: The Purkinje shift refers to:
choices: Sensitivity shift toward shorter wavelengths in dim light
rationale: Scotopic peak sensitivity is ~507 nm vs photopic peak ~555 nm; thus, the eye is more sensitive to blue-green light under dark conditions.

text: The normal critical flicker fusion frequency (CFF) under photopic conditions is about:
rationale: Temporal resolution increases with luminance up to about 60 Hz under photopic conditions.

text: The visual evoked potential primarily reflects activity of the:
rationale: VEP measures cortical response to pattern-reversal stimuli, primarily from V1.

text: The primary substrate for glycolysis is:
rationale: Glucose is converted to pyruvate with net 2 ATP and 2 NADH during glycolysis.

text: The rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis is:
rationale: PFK-1 controls glycolytic flux via regulation by ATP and citrate.

text: In anaerobic conditions, pyruvate is converted to:
rationale: Lactate dehydrogenase regenerates NAD⁺ allowing glycolysis to continue in the absence of oxygen.

text: The main function of the pentose phosphate pathway is to produce:
rationale: The PPP yields NADPH for biosynthesis and antioxidant defense, plus ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis.

text: The lens relies primarily on which pathway for energy production?
rationale: Because it is avascular, the lens depends on glycolysis for ~70% of its ATP.

text: The Cori cycle links:
rationale: Lactate produced by anaerobic muscle is converted back to glucose in the liver.

text: The citric acid cycle occurs in the:
rationale: All TCA enzymes (except succinate dehydrogenase) reside in the mitochondrial matrix.

text: The rate-limiting enzyme of the TCA cycle is:
rationale: Isocitrate dehydrogenase controls NADH production and is regulated by ADP/ATP.

text: The final electron acceptor in oxidative phosphorylation is:
rationale: Oxygen accepts electrons at Complex IV, forming water.

text: Uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation results in:
rationale: Uncouplers dissipate the proton gradient through UCP proteins, generating heat instead of ATP.

text: β-oxidation of fatty acids occurs in the:
rationale: Fatty acyl-CoA enters mitochondria via the carnitine shuttle for sequential removal of 2-carbon units.

text: The carnitine shuttle is necessary for:
choices: Transport of long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria
rationale: Carnitine acyltransferase I regulates the entry step for β-oxidation.

text: The major energy source for corneal epithelium is:
rationale: The corneal epithelium has oxygen access and uses both aerobic and anaerobic glycolysis, with glucose as the primary substrate.

text: Amino acids undergo transamination mainly in the:
rationale: Hepatic aminotransferases convert amino acids to ketoacids for metabolism.

text: The urea cycle detoxifies:
rationale: The liver converts toxic ammonia to urea for renal excretion.

text: The main extracellular cation is:
rationale: Na⁺ predominates in extracellular fluid and largely determines osmotic balance.

text: The main intracellular cation is:
rationale: K⁺ is maintained inside cells by the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase.

text: An increase in ventilation that lowers arterial CO₂ leads to:
rationale: Lower PaCO₂ raises pH, producing respiratory alkalosis.

text: Metabolic acidosis is characterized by:
rationale: HCO₃⁻ falls as it buffers excess acid.

text: The kidney compensates for metabolic acidosis by:
choices: Excreting H⁺ and generating new HCO₃⁻
rationale: Renal tubular cells secrete H⁺ and produce new bicarbonate to restore pH.

text: The anterior pituitary is derived embryologically from:
rationale: Adenohypophysis arises from oral ectoderm (Rathke’s pouch).

text: The posterior pituitary releases:
rationale: Neurohypophysis stores and releases hypothalamic peptides ADH and oxytocin.

text: Which hormone increases blood glucose by promoting gluconeogenesis and lipolysis?
rationale: Cortisol mobilizes substrates and antagonizes insulin.

text: Which hormone lowers blood glucose by increasing cellular uptake?
rationale: Insulin promotes GLUT4-mediated glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis.

text: A deficiency of ADH causes:
rationale: Absent vasopressin prevents water reabsorption, causing dilute polyuria and polydipsia.

text: Graves disease leads to hyperthyroidism through:
rationale: TSI (thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin) mimics TSH at the receptor.

text: Aqueous humor formation depends primarily on:
choices: Active secretion by the nonpigmented ciliary epithelium
rationale: Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase and carbonic anhydrase drive active secretion by the ciliary epithelium.

text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors reduce intraocular pressure by:
choices: Decreasing bicarbonate formation in the ciliary processes
rationale: Less HCO₃⁻ formation reduces aqueous production.

text: The main antioxidant protecting the cornea and lens is:
rationale: Reduced glutathione scavenges reactive species and preserves lens clarity.

text: The retina’s primary energy source is:
rationale: Photoreceptors preferentially use glucose with high aerobic glycolytic flux to support rapid turnover.

text: The first line of immune defense is the:
rationale: Physical barriers and antimicrobial secretions prevent pathogen entry.

text: The key cell type bridging innate and adaptive immunity is the:
rationale: Dendritic cells present antigen to naïve T cells and prime adaptive responses.

text: The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I presents antigens to:
rationale: MHC I displays endogenous peptides to CD8⁺ T cells.

text: MHC class II molecules present antigen to:
rationale: MHC II on professional APCs activates CD4⁺ T helper cells.

text: The primary antibody produced in a first exposure response is:
rationale: IgM is the first class secreted by activated B cells during primary response.

text: The most abundant serum immunoglobulin is:
rationale: IgG constitutes the majority of circulating antibodies and crosses the placenta.

text: The immunoglobulin found predominantly in tears and mucosal secretions is:
rationale: Secretory IgA prevents microbial adherence to ocular and other mucosal surfaces.

text: Which cell type destroys virus-infected cells without prior sensitization?
rationale: NK cells target cells with low MHC I expression and induce apoptosis.

text: Complement activation by antigen-antibody complexes occurs via the:
rationale: C1q binds IgM/IgG, triggering C3 cleavage and membrane attack complex formation.

text: Type I hypersensitivity is mediated by:
rationale: Immediate reactions result from IgE-mediated mast-cell histamine release.

text: Type II hypersensitivity involves:
choices: Antibody-mediated cytotoxicity against cell surface antigens
rationale: IgG/IgM bind cellular antigens leading to complement-mediated lysis or opsonization.

text: Type III hypersensitivity is caused by:
rationale: Circulating antigen–antibody complexes deposit in tissues causing inflammation (e.g., SLE, vasculitis).

text: Type IV hypersensitivity is mediated by:
rationale: Delayed (24–48 h) response driven by sensitized T lymphocytes.

text: An example of Type IV ocular reaction is:
rationale: Phlyctenular disease is a delayed T-cell–mediated response to microbial antigens.

text: Autoimmune destruction of lacrimal and salivary glands is characteristic of:
rationale: Lymphocytic infiltration of lacrimal and salivary glands causes keratoconjunctivitis sicca and xerostomia.

text: The most common bacterial cause of hyperacute conjunctivitis is:
rationale: N. gonorrhoeae can penetrate intact epithelium, causing copious purulent discharge.

text: The leading cause of chronic follicular conjunctivitis worldwide is:
rationale: Ocular trachoma produces pannus and conjunctival scarring.

text: The most common cause of bacterial keratitis in contact-lens wearers is:
rationale: Pseudomonas thrives in lens cases/solutions and can rapidly melt cornea.

text: Dendritic corneal ulcers with terminal bulbs are characteristic of:
rationale: HSV reactivation → branching dendrites with terminal bulbs staining with fluorescein and rose bengal.

text: Pseudodendrites (without bulbs) are most associated with:
rationale: Zoster lesions are elevated with tapered ends and minimal staining.

text: Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC) is caused by:
rationale: EKC often leads to subepithelial infiltrates and pseudomembranes after 10–14 days.

text: Acanthamoeba keratitis is most strongly associated with:
choices: Contact-lens use with tap-water or homemade saline
rationale: Free-living amoebae in water/soil cause ring infiltrate and severe pain.

text: Ocular toxoplasmosis is caused by:
rationale: Reactivation leads to focal necrotizing retinochoroiditis with 'headlight in fog.'

text: Interstitial keratitis in a young adult suggests a history of:
rationale: Treponemal disease causes stromal scarring and ghost vessels.

text: Cotton-wool spots represent:
rationale: Axoplasmic flow blockage causes swollen RNFL in ischemia.

text: The first leukocyte to reach an acute inflammatory site is the:
rationale: Neutrophils arrive within hours to phagocytose bacteria/debris.

text: Chronic inflammation is characterized by:
rationale: Lymphocytes and macrophages dominate with ongoing repair/fibrosis.

text: Caseous necrosis is most typical of:
rationale: Cheese-like necrosis due to mycobacterial granulomas.

text: Granulomatous inflammation is characterized by:
choices: Epithelioid macrophages and multinucleated giant cells
rationale: Seen in TB, sarcoid, some fungi, and phlyctenulosis.

text: Lipid peroxidation is a major mechanism of:
rationale: ROS attack membrane phospholipids, relevant to lens oxidative injury.

text: Vergence (V) is defined as:
choices: Reciprocal of distance (in meters) from a wavefront to the focus
Inverse of focal length in centimeters
rationale: V = n/l (diopters); positive converging, negative diverging.

text: Light entering a +5 D lens from infinity emerges focused at:
choices: 0.10 m in front of the lens
0.25 m in front of the lens

text: For a +4 D lens placed 0.25 m from the eye, the effective power at the eye is closest to:
rationale: Using vertex conversion, F′ ≈ +3.6 D for a +4 D lens at 0.25 m in this setup.

text: The secondary focal point of a –5 D lens lies:
choices: –0.20 m behind the lens (on same side as object)
rationale: Negative lenses have virtual foci on the object side; f = –0.20 m.

text: If object is 25 cm in front of a +4 D lens, image position is:
A –2.00 D lens moved 5 mm closer to the eye changes effective power by approximately:
rationale: ΔF ≈ F² × Δd = 4 × 0.005 = 0.02 D (sign depends on direction; magnitude ≈ 0.02).

text: Back vertex power (BVP) is defined as:
choices: Vergence leaving rear surface when parallel rays enter front surface
Mean front curve minus back curve
rationale: BVP equals emerging vergence at the back surface for parallel incident light.

text: An object at the first principal focus emerges as:
rationale: At F₁, the emergent light is collimated (image at infinity).

text: The principal planes in a thick lens represent:
choices: Reference planes where refraction may be considered to occur
rationale: They’re reference planes simplifying ray tracing through thick systems.

text: Against-the-rule astigmatism has steepest curve:

text: Reducing vertex distance in high myopia spectacles will:
choices: Reduce minification and improve field of view

text: Which optical phenomenon most directly supports the wave theory of light?
rationale: Interference results from the superposition of light waves and demonstrates their wave nature.

text: In Young’s double-slit experiment, increasing the slit separation will:
rationale: Fringe spacing is inversely proportional to slit separation; wider spacing reduces the distance between fringes.

text: Polarization of light can be achieved by all of the following except:
rationale: Diffraction bends waves at apertures/edges; it does not polarize light.

text: A Nicol prism functions primarily as a:
rationale: Using calcite birefringence and total internal reflection, it passes one polarization state.

text: Which type of interference results in increased reflected light intensity?
rationale: In-phase waves add amplitudes, increasing brightness.

text: An anti-reflective coating is based on which principle?
rationale: Reflections from coating/air and coating/substrate cancel when out of phase.

text: Diffraction effects are more pronounced when:
choices: Aperture size is small compared to wavelength
rationale: Small apertures create spreading comparable to the wavelength.

text: Which optical element most clearly demonstrates diffraction in the clinical setting?
rationale: Pinhole apertures generate diffraction patterns that can limit acuity.

text: Which best describes Brewster’s angle?
choices: Angle of incidence that results in complete polarization of reflected light
rationale: At this angle, reflected and refracted rays are orthogonal and reflection is fully polarized.

text: The human eye’s peak spectral sensitivity under photopic conditions is approximately:
rationale: Cone-mediated luminance peaks near 555 nm (green–yellow).

text: Which law describes the inverse relationship between luminance threshold and stimulus area up to a critical size?
rationale: Ricco’s law (L × A = constant) applies under complete spatial summation.

text: Temporal summation is best described by which relationship?
rationale: Bloch’s law: for brief stimuli (<~100 ms), detectability depends on total luminance energy.

text: Weber’s law expresses the relationship between:
rationale: ΔI/I = k; sensitivity depends on relative luminance change.

text: The Purkinje shift refers to:
choices: Shift of peak visual sensitivity toward shorter wavelengths under scotopic conditions
Loss of contrast in bright light
Increase in luminance thresholds with adaptation
rationale: Rod dominance shifts peak sensitivity to ~507 nm (blue–green).

text: Which mechanism contributes most to the Stiles–Crawford effect?
rationale: Cones act as waveguides; off-axis light is less effective.

text: Which drug causes cycloplegia by blocking muscarinic receptors?
rationale: Tropicamide blocks M3 receptors, producing mydriasis and cycloplegia.

text: Which of the following is a direct-acting cholinergic agonist?
rationale: Pilocarpine directly stimulates muscarinic receptors.

text: Which drug decreases aqueous humor production via beta blockade?
rationale: Timolol reduces aqueous formation by the ciliary epithelium.

text: A patient with asthma should avoid which glaucoma medication?
rationale: Non-selective beta blockers can trigger bronchospasm.

text: Which prostaglandin analog increases uveoscleral outflow?
rationale: Latanoprost (PGF2α analog) enhances uveoscleral outflow.

text: Which drug class is most associated with elevated IOP during chronic use?
rationale: Steroids increase TM resistance and can raise IOP.

text: Which antibiotic can cause gray-brown corneal deposits?
rationale: Amiodarone can cause vortex keratopathy with gray-brown deposits.

text: Which drug may cause optic neuropathy with prolonged use?
rationale: Ethambutol toxicity produces bilateral cecocentral scotomas.

text: Which drug can cause bull’s-eye maculopathy?
rationale: Hydroxychloroquine accumulates in the RPE and parafovea.

text: Which systemic drug may cause blue scleral discoloration?
rationale: Minocycline can cause blue-gray pigmentation of sclera and skin.

text: Which cycloplegic agent has the longest duration of action?
rationale: Atropine’s cycloplegia/mydriasis can persist 7–10 days.

text: Which cycloplegic agent is best for routine refraction in children due to rapid onset and short duration?
rationale: Cyclopentolate gives strong, short-lived cycloplegia ideal for pediatrics.

text: Which topical adrenergic agonist is commonly used for diagnostic dilation?
rationale: Phenylephrine stimulates the iris dilator without cycloplegia.

text: Which drug combination is contraindicated in narrow-angle glaucoma?
rationale: Combined mydriasis can precipitate angle closure in narrow angles.

text: Which beta blocker demonstrates intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA)?
rationale: Carteolol’s partial agonism may reduce systemic side effects.

text: Which carbonic anhydrase inhibitor is available as a topical formulation?
rationale: Topical CAIs include dorzolamide (and brinzolamide); acetazolamide/methazolamide are systemic.

text: Which alpha-2 agonist both decreases aqueous production and increases uveoscleral outflow?
rationale: Brimonidine has a dual mechanism useful as adjunct therapy.

text: Which of the following drugs can cause Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS)?
rationale: Sulfa-based agents are linked to severe mucocutaneous reactions.

text: Which topical antiviral is used for epithelial HSV keratitis?
rationale: Ganciclovir 0.15% gel is preferred for HSV epithelial disease.

text: Which systemic antiviral provides prophylaxis for recurrent HSV keratitis?
rationale: Oral acyclovir suppresses recurrences by inhibiting viral DNA polymerase.

text: Which antifungal is used topically for fungal keratitis?
rationale: Natamycin 5% is the only commercially available topical antifungal in the U.S.

text: Which topical antibiotic is most effective against Pseudomonas in CL-related keratitis?
rationale: Fluoroquinolones are first-line for contact-lens–related Pseudomonas ulcers.

text: Which topical antibiotic is primarily Gram-positive coverage?
rationale: Bacitracin targets Gram-positive cocci; often paired with polymyxin B.

text: Which systemic antibiotic can cause pseudotumor cerebri?
rationale: Tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline) can elevate intracranial pressure.

text: Which systemic medication is most associated with blue-yellow color vision defects?
rationale: Digoxin toxicity causes xanthopsia and blue–yellow dyschromatopsia.

text: Which systemic medication can cause NAION due to vasoconstriction and hypotension?
rationale: PDE-5 inhibitors have been linked to NAION in susceptible patients.

text: Which medication may cause crystalline retinopathy with high cumulative dose?
rationale: Tamoxifen can produce intraretinal crystals and macular edema.

text: Which medication is most associated with vortex keratopathy?
rationale: Amiodarone accumulates in basal epithelium, forming whorl-like patterns.

text: Which systemic medication is most associated with pigmentary retinopathy and nyctalopia?
rationale: High-dose thioridazine can damage RPE/photoreceptors causing night blindness.

text: Which topical steroid has the lowest risk of raising IOP?
rationale: Loteprednol is ester-based and rapidly deactivated, minimizing IOP elevation.

text: Cotton-wool spots result from:
choices: Axoplasmic flow stasis in retinal nerve fiber layer
rationale: Cotton-wool spots represent focal ischemia of nerve fiber axons due to microvascular occlusion—common in diabetes and hypertension.

text: Which retinal finding best distinguishes hypertensive retinopathy from diabetic retinopathy?
rationale: AV nicking is a hallmark of chronic arteriolar sclerosis and compression, specific to hypertensive retinopathy.

text: Which endocrine disorder produces exophthalmos due to inflammatory orbital infiltration?
rationale: Graves ophthalmopathy involves autoimmune inflammation of extraocular muscles and orbital fat, producing proptosis.

text: A patient with chronic dry eye, parotid swelling, and arthralgia most likely has:
rationale: Sjögren’s involves autoimmune destruction of lacrimal and salivary glands, causing keratoconjunctivitis sicca.

text: Sarcoidosis most often causes which ocular finding?
rationale: Sarcoid uveitis typically presents with mutton-fat KPs and iris nodules due to granulomatous inflammation.

text: A positive FTA-ABS test and Argyll Robertson pupils suggest:
rationale: Argyll Robertson pupils (light–near dissociation) are classic for neurosyphilis; FTA-ABS confirms diagnosis.

text: Which infection causes chorioretinitis with congenital transmission?
rationale: Congenital toxoplasmosis causes bilateral macular scars and active necrotizing retinitis in children.

text: A patient with erythema migrans and cranial nerve palsy likely has:
rationale: Lyme disease (Borrelia burgdorferi) can cause uveitis and CN VI palsy; erythema migrans is a diagnostic clue.

text: Retinal periphlebitis with “candle-wax drippings” is most associated with:
rationale: Segmental perivenous sheathing and exudation are classic retinal signs of sarcoid vasculitis.

text: Which infectious disease produces granulomatous uveitis and a positive PPD test?
rationale: Mycobacterium tuberculosis may cause anterior or posterior uveitis with caseating granulomas.

text: Which autoimmune disorder may cause scleritis and peripheral ulcerative keratitis?
rationale: RA can produce necrotizing scleritis and peripheral corneal melt due to immune-complex vasculitis.

text: A lupus patient with blurry vision, cotton-wool spots, and vascular sheathing likely has:
rationale: Immune-complex deposition in SLE causes retinal ischemia mimicking hypertensive retinopathy.

text: Which finding suggests ocular involvement in HIV?
choices: Cotton-wool spots with minimal hemorrhage (HIV retinopathy)
rationale: HIV retinopathy causes microangiopathy with CWS and microaneurysms, often asymptomatic.

text: Cytomegalovirus retinitis typically occurs when CD4 counts fall below:
rationale: CMV retinitis appears in advanced AIDS with CD4 < 50; presents as necrotizing retinitis with hemorrhage.

text: A Hollenhorst plaque at the retinal arteriole suggests:
rationale: Cholesterol emboli originate from carotid atheroma, commonly detected at branch points.

text: Which systemic condition increases risk for central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)?
rationale: Chronic hypertension causes venous compression at AV crossings, predisposing to CRVO.

text: Cherry-red spot at the macula indicates:
rationale: CRAO causes inner retinal infarction, leaving the foveal choroidal background as a red spot.

text: Which systemic disease commonly causes ocular ischemic syndrome (OIS)?
rationale: OIS results from ≥90% carotid occlusion, reducing ophthalmic artery perfusion; mid-peripheral hemorrhages are classic.

text: Which malignancy most often metastasizes to the choroid?
rationale: Breast cancer is the leading source of ocular metastases, usually to the choroid.

text: A 60-year-old smoker with painless monocular vision loss and pale optic disc likely has:
rationale: Arteritic AION (GCA) presents with chalky-white disc and systemic inflammatory signs.

text: Which laboratory tests confirm diagnosis of GCA?
choices: ESR, CRP, and temporal artery biopsy
rationale: Temporal artery biopsy with elevated ESR/CRP confirms GCA; treat urgently with systemic steroids.

text: Which autoimmune condition produces episcleritis with nodular tenderness but no vision loss?
rationale: RA-associated episcleritis is typically benign and self-limiting; scleritis indicates more severe disease.

text: Which systemic condition is most associated with bilateral optic disc edema and normal MRI?
rationale: IIH presents with papilledema, normal neuroimaging, and elevated LP opening pressure.

text: Which systemic drug causes pseudotumor cerebri?
rationale: Tetracyclines, vitamin A, and isotretinoin are associated with intracranial hypertension.

text: Which vitamin deficiency produces night blindness and Bitot’s spots?
rationale: Vitamin A is required for rhodopsin regeneration; deficiency causes xerophthalmia and nyctalopia.

text: Which systemic medication can cause whorl keratopathy and anterior subcapsular cataract?
rationale: Amiodarone may deposit in corneal epithelium (vortex pattern) and lens epithelium with long use.

text: Which disease causes optic neuritis with bilateral vision loss and longitudinally extensive MRI lesions?
rationale: NMO presents with severe bilateral ON and spinal lesions; aquaporin-4 antibody positive.

text: Which systemic condition can cause microaneurysms, dot hemorrhages, and macular edema?
rationale: Diabetic retinopathy results from microvascular pericyte loss and capillary leakage.

text: Which systemic condition may cause Roth spots?
rationale: Roth spots (hemorrhage with white center) occur from septic emboli in bacterial endocarditis.

text: Which autoimmune disease causes bilateral parotid enlargement and positive anti-Ro/SSA antibodies?
rationale: Anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB are diagnostic of Sjögren’s; affects salivary and lacrimal glands.

text: Which extraocular muscle is innervated by cranial nerve IV?
rationale: The superior oblique is the only muscle supplied by the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

text: A lesion at the right optic tract produces which field defect?
rationale: Post-chiasmal lesions cause contralateral homonymous field loss.

text: A right oculomotor nerve palsy presents with all of the following except:
rationale: CN III palsy causes ptosis, mydriasis, and 'down-and-out' position; abduction deficit suggests CN VI palsy.

text: Which muscle is primarily responsible for depression when the eye is adducted?
rationale: Superior oblique depresses the adducted eye most effectively.

text: The afferent pupillary pathway terminates in which midbrain structure?
rationale: The pretectal nucleus relays light information bilaterally to EW nuclei for pupillary constriction.

text: Damage to the right optic nerve before the chiasm will cause:
rationale: Pre-chiasmal lesions affect the ipsilateral eye only.

text: Which extraocular muscle originates from the annulus of Zinn and inserts farthest from the limbus?
rationale: The superior rectus inserts ~7.7 mm from the limbus—farthest among the recti.

text: The optic radiations pass through which cerebral lobe to reach the visual cortex?
rationale: Inferior fibers (Meyer’s loop) travel through temporal lobe; superior fibers via parietal lobe to V1.

text: A lesion of the right parietal lobe causes:
rationale: Parietal lesions affect superior optic radiations, producing contralateral inferior field loss.

text: Which fibers decussate in the optic chiasm?
rationale: Nasal fibers cross to the opposite side; temporal remain uncrossed.

text: A pituitary adenoma most likely produces which field defect?
rationale: Chiasmal compression affects crossing nasal fibers, producing temporal field loss.

text: Which artery supplies the inner retinal layers?
rationale: The central retinal artery branches supply the inner two-thirds of the retina.

text: Which vessel primarily supplies the outer retina and photoreceptors?
rationale: The choriocapillaris, from the short posterior ciliary arteries, nourishes the outer retina.

text: Which cranial nerve mediates the corneal blink reflex (afferent limb)?
rationale: The nasociliary branch of V1 senses corneal touch; CN VII executes the blink.

text: The efferent limb of the corneal blink reflex is mediated by:
rationale: Facial nerve innervates orbicularis oculi, producing eyelid closure.

text: Which EOM passes through the trochlea before inserting on the globe?
rationale: The superior oblique passes through a fibrocartilaginous pulley (trochlea) before inserting posteriorly.

text: Which pupillary abnormality is associated with dorsal midbrain syndrome?
rationale: Dorsal midbrain (Parinaud’s) causes impaired upgaze and light-near dissociation due to pretectal injury.

text: Which condition shows a tonic dilated pupil with absent light reaction but near constriction?
rationale: Adie’s pupil results from postganglionic parasympathetic damage; light reaction lost, near response slow.

text: Which pupillary pattern is pathognomonic for optic nerve disease?
rationale: RAPD occurs with asymmetric optic nerve function due to decreased afferent input.

text: A lesion in the left lateral geniculate nucleus will cause:
rationale: The left LGN carries right visual field information; lesion → right homonymous hemianopia.

text: A patient with left internuclear ophthalmoplegia has a lesion in the:
rationale: The MLF links contralateral abducens to ipsilateral oculomotor; a left MLF lesion impairs left adduction.

text: Which structure serves as the major relay for visual input to the primary visual cortex?
rationale: The LGN receives retinal input and projects to V1 via the optic radiations.

text: Which visual pathway structure is part of the midbrain?
rationale: The superior colliculus is a midbrain structure involved in eye movements and saccades.

text: Which embryologic layer gives rise to the retina and optic nerve?
rationale: The optic cup and stalk develop from neuroectoderm of the diencephalon.

text: The corneal epithelium originates from which embryonic layer?
rationale: The corneal epithelium develops from surface ectoderm; endothelium derives from neural crest.

text: Neural crest cells contribute to all of the following except:
rationale: The lens arises from surface ectoderm, not neural crest.

text: At birth, which ocular structure is anatomically immature?
rationale: The macula/fovea mature postnatally, reaching adult structure by ~4 years.

text: Which is the most likely cause of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction?
choices: Membrane persistence at the valve of Hasner
rationale: Failure of canalization at the valve of Hasner leads to epiphora in infants.

text: Which developmental anomaly presents with a small cornea and iris-to-cornea adhesions?
rationale: Axenfeld–Rieger involves anterior segment dysgenesis from abnormal neural crest migration.

text: Which ocular condition most commonly causes sensory deprivation amblyopia in infants?
rationale: Dense congenital cataracts block form vision during the critical period, leading to amblyopia.

text: A patient with erythema migrans and cranial nerve palsy likely has:
rationale: Lyme disease (Borrelia burgdorferi) can cause uveitis and CN VI palsy; erythema migrans is a diagnostic clue.

text: Retinal periphlebitis with “candle-wax drippings” is most associated with:
rationale: Segmental perivenous sheathing and exudation are classic retinal signs of sarcoid vasculitis.

text: Which infectious disease produces granulomatous uveitis and a positive PPD test?
rationale: Mycobacterium tuberculosis may cause anterior or posterior uveitis with caseating granulomas.

text: Which autoimmune disorder may cause scleritis and peripheral ulcerative keratitis?
rationale: RA can produce necrotizing scleritis and peripheral corneal melt due to immune-complex vasculitis.

text: A lupus patient with blurry vision, cotton-wool spots, and vascular sheathing likely has:
rationale: Immune-complex deposition in SLE causes retinal ischemia mimicking hypertensive retinopathy.

text: Which finding suggests ocular involvement in HIV?
choices: Cotton-wool spots with minimal hemorrhage (HIV retinopathy)
rationale: HIV retinopathy causes microangiopathy with CWS and microaneurysms, often asymptomatic.

text: Cytomegalovirus retinitis typically occurs when CD4 counts fall below:
rationale: CMV retinitis appears in advanced AIDS with CD4 < 50; presents as necrotizing retinitis with hemorrhage.

text: A Hollenhorst plaque at the retinal arteriole suggests:
rationale: Cholesterol emboli originate from carotid atheroma, commonly detected at branch points.

text: Which systemic condition increases risk for central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)?
rationale: Chronic hypertension causes venous compression at AV crossings, predisposing to CRVO.

text: Cherry-red spot at the macula indicates:
rationale: CRAO causes inner retinal infarction, leaving the foveal choroidal background as a red spot.

text: Which systemic disease commonly causes ocular ischemic syndrome (OIS)?
rationale: OIS results from ≥90% carotid occlusion, reducing ophthalmic artery perfusion; mid-peripheral hemorrhages are classic.

text: Which malignancy most often metastasizes to the choroid?
rationale: Breast cancer is the leading source of ocular metastases, usually to the choroid.

text: A 60-year-old smoker with painless monocular vision loss and pale optic disc likely has:
rationale: Arteritic AION (GCA) presents with chalky-white disc and systemic inflammatory signs.

text: Which laboratory tests confirm diagnosis of GCA?
choices: ESR, CRP, and temporal artery biopsy
rationale: Temporal artery biopsy with elevated ESR/CRP confirms GCA; treat urgently with systemic steroids.

text: Which autoimmune condition produces episcleritis with nodular tenderness but no vision loss?
rationale: RA-associated episcleritis is typically benign and self-limiting; scleritis indicates more severe disease.

text: Which systemic condition is most associated with bilateral optic disc edema and normal MRI?
rationale: IIH presents with papilledema, normal neuroimaging, and elevated LP opening pressure.

text: Which systemic drug causes pseudotumor cerebri?
rationale: Tetracyclines, vitamin A, and isotretinoin are associated with intracranial hypertension.

text: Which vitamin deficiency produces night blindness and Bitot’s spots?
rationale: Vitamin A is required for rhodopsin regeneration; deficiency causes xerophthalmia and nyctalopia.

text: Which systemic medication can cause whorl keratopathy and anterior subcapsular cataract?
rationale: Amiodarone may deposit in corneal epithelium (vortex pattern) and lens epithelium with long use.

text: Which disease causes optic neuritis with bilateral vision loss and longitudinally extensive MRI lesions?
rationale: NMO presents with severe bilateral ON and spinal lesions; aquaporin-4 antibody positive.

text: Which systemic condition can cause microaneurysms, dot hemorrhages, and macular edema?
rationale: Diabetic retinopathy results from microvascular pericyte loss and capillary leakage.

text: Which systemic condition may cause Roth spots?
rationale: Roth spots (hemorrhage with white center) occur from septic emboli in bacterial endocarditis.

text: Which autoimmune disease causes bilateral parotid enlargement and positive anti-Ro/SSA antibodies?
rationale: Anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB are diagnostic of Sjögren’s; affects salivary and lacrimal glands.

text: Which extraocular muscle is innervated by cranial nerve IV?
rationale: The superior oblique is the only muscle supplied by the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

text: A lesion at the right optic tract produces which field defect?
rationale: Post-chiasmal lesions cause contralateral homonymous field loss.

text: A right oculomotor nerve palsy presents with all of the following except:
rationale: CN III palsy causes ptosis, mydriasis, and 'down-and-out' position; abduction deficit suggests CN VI palsy.

text: Which muscle is primarily responsible for depression when the eye is adducted?
rationale: Superior oblique depresses the adducted eye most effectively.

text: The afferent pupillary pathway terminates in which midbrain structure?
rationale: The pretectal nucleus relays light information bilaterally to EW nuclei for pupillary constriction.

text: Damage to the right optic nerve before the chiasm will cause:
rationale: Pre-chiasmal lesions affect the ipsilateral eye only.

text: Which extraocular muscle originates from the annulus of Zinn and inserts farthest from the limbus?
rationale: The superior rectus inserts ~7.7 mm from the limbus—farthest among the recti.

text: The optic radiations pass through which cerebral lobe to reach the visual cortex?
rationale: Inferior fibers (Meyer’s loop) travel through temporal lobe; superior fibers via parietal lobe to V1.

text: A lesion of the right parietal lobe causes:
rationale: Parietal lesions affect superior optic radiations, producing contralateral inferior field loss.

text: Which fibers decussate in the optic chiasm?
rationale: Nasal fibers cross to the opposite side; temporal remain uncrossed.

text: A pituitary adenoma most likely produces which field defect?
rationale: Chiasmal compression affects crossing nasal fibers, producing temporal field loss.

text: Which artery supplies the inner retinal layers?
rationale: The central retinal artery branches supply the inner two-thirds of the retina.

text: Which vessel primarily supplies the outer retina and photoreceptors?
rationale: The choriocapillaris, from the short posterior ciliary arteries, nourishes the outer retina.

text: Which cranial nerve mediates the corneal blink reflex (afferent limb)?
rationale: The nasociliary branch of V1 senses corneal touch; CN VII executes the blink.

text: The efferent limb of the corneal blink reflex is mediated by:
rationale: Facial nerve innervates orbicularis oculi, producing eyelid closure.

text: Which EOM passes through the trochlea before inserting on the globe?
rationale: The superior oblique passes through a fibrocartilaginous pulley (trochlea) before inserting posteriorly.

text: Which pupillary abnormality is associated with dorsal midbrain syndrome?
rationale: Dorsal midbrain (Parinaud’s) causes impaired upgaze and light-near dissociation due to pretectal injury.

text: Which condition shows a tonic dilated pupil with absent light reaction but near constriction?
rationale: Adie’s pupil results from postganglionic parasympathetic damage; light reaction lost, near response slow.

text: Which pupillary pattern is pathognomonic for optic nerve disease?
rationale: RAPD occurs with asymmetric optic nerve function due to decreased afferent input.

text: A lesion in the left lateral geniculate nucleus will cause:
rationale: The left LGN carries right visual field information; lesion → right homonymous hemianopia.

text: A patient with left internuclear ophthalmoplegia has a lesion in the:
rationale: The MLF links contralateral abducens to ipsilateral oculomotor; a left MLF lesion impairs left adduction.

text: Which structure serves as the major relay for visual input to the primary visual cortex?
rationale: The LGN receives retinal input and projects to V1 via the optic radiations.

text: Which visual pathway structure is part of the midbrain?
rationale: The superior colliculus is a midbrain structure involved in eye movements and saccades.

text: Which embryologic layer gives rise to the retina and optic nerve?
rationale: The optic cup and stalk develop from neuroectoderm of the diencephalon.

text: The corneal epithelium originates from which embryonic layer?
rationale: The corneal epithelium develops from surface ectoderm; endothelium derives from neural crest.

text: Neural crest cells contribute to all of the following except:
rationale: The lens arises from surface ectoderm, not neural crest.

text: At birth, which ocular structure is anatomically immature?
rationale: The macula/fovea mature postnatally, reaching adult structure by ~4 years.

text: Which is the most likely cause of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction?
choices: Membrane persistence at the valve of Hasner
rationale: Failure of canalization at the valve of Hasner leads to epiphora in infants.

text: Which developmental anomaly presents with a small cornea and iris-to-cornea adhesions?
rationale: Axenfeld–Rieger involves anterior segment dysgenesis from abnormal neural crest migration.

text: Which ocular condition most commonly causes sensory deprivation amblyopia in infants?
rationale: Dense congenital cataracts block form vision during the critical period, leading to amblyopia.

text: The most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults is:
rationale: S. aureus is the most frequent cause in adults; in children, H. influenzae and S. pneumoniae predominate.

text: Which organism causes hyperacute purulent conjunctivitis with possible corneal perforation?
rationale: N. gonorrhoeae penetrates an intact cornea and can cause rapid ulceration—an ophthalmic emergency.

text: Inclusion conjunctivitis is most often caused by:
rationale: Adult inclusion conjunctivitis results from sexually transmitted C. trachomatis D–K, often unilateral with follicles.

text: Pannus formation and Herbert’s pits are characteristic of:
rationale: Chronic trachoma causes superior limbal scarring and Herbert’s pits at resolved follicles.

text: Which adenoviral serotypes most commonly cause epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC)?
rationale: EKC—highly contagious—shows subepithelial infiltrates; serotypes 8, 19, 37 predominate.

text: Phlyctenulosis is a hypersensitivity reaction to:
rationale: Type IV delayed hypersensitivity to bacterial proteins causes limbal nodules with tearing and photophobia.

text: A dendritic ulcer with terminal bulbs stains best with:
rationale: HSV epithelial ulcers stain brightly with fluorescein and rose bengal at edges.

text: The primary treatment for HSV epithelial keratitis is:
rationale: Topical antivirals shorten duration; steroids are contraindicated in active epithelial disease.

text: Recurrent HSV stromal keratitis is prevented by:
rationale: Prophylactic oral antivirals reduce recurrence by ~50%.

text: A pseudodendrite with minimal staining is characteristic of:
rationale: VZV lesions have tapered ends and less staining, unlike HSV dendrites.

text: Band keratopathy results from deposition of:
rationale: Chronic uveitis or hypercalcemia causes calcium deposits in Bowman’s and anterior stroma.

text: Kayser–Fleischer rings indicate accumulation of:
rationale: Seen in Wilson’s disease; brown-green ring from copper deposition circumferentially.

text: Fleischer ring and Vogt’s striae are associated with:
rationale: Fleischer = iron deposition at cone base; Vogt’s = stress lines.

text: The most common corneal dystrophy affecting the epithelium is:
rationale: Meesmann’s presents with intraepithelial cysts and mild foreign-body sensation.

text: A honeycomb pattern in Bowman’s layer indicates:
rationale: Reis-Bücklers affects Bowman’s; recurrent erosions are common.

text: Amyloid deposits with branching refractile lines on slit-lamp suggest:
rationale: Amyloid fibrils create lattice lines—autosomal-dominant stromal dystrophy.

text: Guttae on specular microscopy indicate dysfunction of:
rationale: Fuchs’ dystrophy shows endothelial loss, corneal edema, and central guttae.

text: The most common eyelid malignancy is:
rationale: BCC forms pearly borders with ulceration, usually lower lid.

text: A yellow plaque on the tarsal conjunctiva in elderly patients is:
rationale: Pinguecula is elastotic degeneration of conjunctiva due to UV exposure.

text: A triangular fibrovascular growth extending onto the cornea is:
rationale: Pterygium results from UV exposure and chronic irritation; may induce astigmatism.

text: Flame-shaped hemorrhages localize to which retinal layer?
rationale: Flame hemorrhages follow the course of NFL fibers.

text: Dot-blot hemorrhages occur in which retinal layer?
choices: Inner nuclear and outer plexiform layers
rationale: Deep capillary leakage leads to dot-blot hemorrhages—classic for diabetic retinopathy.

text: A cherry-red spot at the macula is seen in:
rationale: CRAO infarcts inner retina leaving foveal choroidal reflection visible.

text: “Blood and thunder” fundus refers to:
rationale: Diffuse hemorrhages and dilated veins from venous stasis cause this classic appearance.

text: Macular star exudates with neuroretinitis are characteristic of:
rationale: Optic disc edema with macular star is diagnostic of Bartonella neuroretinitis.

text: Drusen between RPE and Bruch’s membrane indicate:
rationale: Deposits cause RPE dysfunction and photoreceptor loss in AMD.

text: Which finding distinguishes wet from dry AMD?
rationale: Neovascular leakage defines the exudative (wet) form of AMD.

text: Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) involves:
rationale: CSR occurs in type A males, associated with stress and steroids.

text: A well-defined yellow subretinal lesion with “orange pigment” and low internal reflectivity on B-scan is:
rationale: Choroidal melanoma shows acoustic hollowness and lipofuscin pigment.

text: Retinitis pigmentosa primarily affects which retinal cells?
rationale: Rod degeneration leads to night blindness and peripheral field constriction.

text: The hallmark of glaucomatous optic-nerve damage is:
choices: Progressive retinal nerve-fiber layer thinning and cupping
rationale: Glaucoma causes gradual loss of retinal ganglion cells, increasing cup-to-disc ratio and NFL defects.

text: Which visual-field pattern is most specific for glaucoma?
rationale: NFL bundles respect the horizontal raphe, creating Bjerrum arcuate and nasal step patterns.

text: The most important modifiable risk factor for glaucoma progression is:
rationale: Lowering IOP slows progression in all glaucoma types.

text: Which layer of the optic nerve head is primarily damaged in glaucoma?
rationale: Axonal compression and posterior bowing at the lamina cribrosa lead to nerve-fiber loss.

text: Which medication reduces aqueous production by beta-blockade?
rationale: Topical beta-blockers decrease aqueous formation via ciliary-epithelium beta-2 receptors.

text: Which drug increases uveoscleral outflow by remodeling extracellular matrix?
rationale: Prostaglandin analogs enhance uveoscleral outflow and are first-line agents for POAG.

text: Which glaucoma agent is contraindicated in asthma or COPD?
rationale: Systemic beta-blockade can exacerbate bronchospasm.

text: Which drug is most likely to cause miosis and brow ache?
rationale: Cholinergic agonists stimulate ciliary muscle contraction → brow ache and miosis.

text: Which finding suggests angle-closure glaucoma?
choices: Mid-dilated fixed pupil with shallow anterior chamber
rationale: Pupillary block causes iris bombé, shallow chamber, and painful IOP spike.

text: The definitive treatment for pupillary-block angle closure is:
rationale: LPI creates an alternate aqueous pathway from posterior to anterior chamber.

text: Which secondary glaucoma is associated with Krukenberg spindle and mid-peripheral iris transillumination defects?
rationale: Liberated pigment clogs the trabecular meshwork, elevating IOP.

text: White flake-like material on the lens capsule and angle structures suggests:
rationale: PXF is linked to systemic vascular disease and weak zonules.

text: A unilateral glaucoma with corectopia and “hammered silver” endothelium describes:
rationale: Abnormal endothelial membrane causes iris adhesions and secondary angle closure.

text: Which optic-neuropathy shows pallor > cupping with disc swelling that resolves in weeks?
rationale: NAION is vascular, often altitudinal, and associated with a “disc at risk.”

text: Which feature distinguishes papilledema from optic neuritis?
choices: Bilateral disc swelling with preserved visual acuity (initially)
rationale: Papilledema is due to raised intracranial pressure; vision initially normal until late stages.

text: Which of the following drugs acts as a prostaglandin analog to increase uveoscleral outflow?
rationale: Latanoprost, a PGF2α analog, enhances uveoscleral outflow via extracellular matrix remodeling.

text: Which drug can cause irreversible brown pigmentation of the iris and eyelids with chronic use?
rationale: Prostaglandin analogs may cause increased melanin synthesis in iris melanocytes and periocular skin.

text: Which systemic medication can cause optic neuritis and color vision changes?
rationale: Ethambutol causes dose-related toxic optic neuropathy with central scotoma and red-green dyschromatopsia.

text: Which ocular emergency requires immediate irrigation followed by cycloplegia and topical antibiotic?
rationale: Alkali injuries rapidly penetrate cornea; copious irrigation and cycloplegia prevent synechiae.

text: In public health, the leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide is:
rationale: Cataract remains the top cause of reversible blindness; trachoma and glaucoma follow globally.
